Literature Review: Structural Maintenance of Chromosomes (SMC) complexes are pivotal in the organization and regulation of chromosomes across the cell cycle. These complexes, which include cohesin, condensin, and the SMC5/6 complex, are essential for processes such as sister chromatid cohesion, chromosome condensation, and DNA repair. Recent advancements in single-molecule studies have shed light on the mechanism of DNA loop extrusion by SMC complexes, a process critical for genome organization and function. This literature review explores the roles of SMC complexes in chromosome biology, focusing on the biophysical aspects of DNA loop extrusion and its implications for genome architecture. SMC complexes are known to extrude loops of DNA, thereby facilitating the spatial organization of the genome within the nucleus. This loop extrusion activity is crucial for the segregation of chromosomes during mitosis and meiosis, as well as for the regulation of gene expression. The mechanism by which SMC complexes extrude DNA loops has been a subject of intense investigation. Single-molecule studies have provided insights into the dynamics of loop extrusion, revealing that SMC complexes can translocate along DNA, extruding loops in a processive manner. These studies have also highlighted the role of ATP hydrolysis in driving the conformational changes necessary for loop extrusion. Despite these advances, the detailed molecular mechanism of loop extrusion by SMC complexes remains to be fully elucidated. The consequences of DNA loop extrusion by SMC complexes for genome organization are profound. By organizing the genome into loops, SMC complexes facilitate the formation of topologically associating domains (TADs), which are regions of the genome that preferentially interact with themselves. TADs are thought to play a key role in the regulation of gene expression by bringing enhancers into proximity with their target genes. Furthermore, the loop extrusion activity of SMC complexes is essential for the resolution of sister chromatids during cell division, ensuring the accurate segregation of chromosomes. In conclusion, SMC complexes play a critical role in the organization and regulation of the genome through their ability to extrude DNA loops. Single-molecule studies have advanced our understanding of the biophysical aspects of loop extrusion, but further research is needed to fully elucidate the molecular mechanism of this process. The implications of DNA loop extrusion for genome architecture and function underscore the importance of SMC complexes in chromosome biology.
